media.description:
Test for IR transparency with remote control and camera.  
In this case I'm using a Galaxy Note 3 cell phone camera.
media.title: 20150809_111355.jpg

media.description:
Lit IR LED appears purple, this is normal.

Sometimes cameras have internal IR filters and this test fails.
This is also a good way to test your remote batteries when in doubt.

It appears subdued to me, this could be due to low batteries in the remote, or more likely, an anti-IR coating somewhere in the camera lens, but some IR is getting through.
media.title: 20150809_111358.jpg

media.description:
These are materials that I know for certain are visible light opaque, and IR transparent.

In the baggie are IR lenses from remotes. 
The dome on the right is a military surplus IR passive cover for headlights.
In my hand and on the desk are exposed developed 35mm film leaders.
media.title: 20150809_113244.jpg

media.description:
How my desk looks through the film leader.
If it were purely visible opaque IR transparent, this scene would appear purple, it is clearly letting a little red light through.
media.title: 20150809_113310.jpg

media.description: Light without IR filter.
media.title: 20150809_113730.jpg

media.description:
Looking directly at the halogen lamp filament through the headlight filter.
Note the purple tint of this camera detecting IR light.  Anything IR this camera sees will appear that shade of purple.
This lens is very very opaque, I think it is intended to be used with night vision equipment.
media.title: 20150809_113726.jpg

media.description:
So I saw online that floppy disk material is visible light opaque and IR transparent.
Let's have a look!
media.title: 20150809_111205.jpg

media.description: Floppy disk disassembly
media.title: 20150809_111307.jpg

media.description:
This space intentionally left black.

This is looking at the remote from the phone through the disk with the remote off.
media.title: 20150809_111448.jpg

media.description:
And with the remote on.
It clearly made it through, but auto-focus didn't stand a chance with this experiment.
Note it is the same shade of purple we saw earlier.
media.title: 20150809_111453.jpg

media.description:
Let's have a look outside through the floppy disk

If IR is coming through, it's purplish influence is being swamped by visible light.
media.title: 20150809_111525.jpg

media.description: It certainly appears red, but remember the IR from the remote looked purple.
media.title: 20150809_111552.jpg

media.description:
The sky does appear much brighter as I would expect in an IR picture.  
I still don't see this as conclusive.
media.title: 20150809_111558.jpg

media.description: Natural light for comparison.
media.title: 20150809_111612.jpg

media.description:
A pic through the disk
I think some light leaked around though.
media.title: 20150809_111646.jpg

media.description: Reference pic.
media.title: 20150809_111650.jpg

media.description:
Final pic through the disk.
The bright sidewalks and dark foliage are consistent with IR, but I would expect this to look more odd if it were pure IR.
media.title: 20150809_111715.jpg

media.description: Natural light
media.title: 20150809_111720.jpg

media.description:
Outside through one film leader.

Clearly plenty of visible light is getting through to colorize this photo, more leaders should be stacked.
media.title: 20150809_113406.jpg

media.description: Natural light
media.title: 20150809_113417.jpg

media.description:
Through the film leader
Once again, the bright sky, relatively brighter pavement, and  dark foliage are indicative of IR.
media.title: 20150809_113423.jpg

media.description: Knockout roses through film leader
media.title: 20150809_113456.jpg

media.description: Natural light
media.title: 20150809_113507.jpg

media.description:
Plants through exposed film leader.
Note the detail that pops out on the hostas in the background.
media.title: 20150809_113538.jpg

media.description: Natural light
media.title: 20150809_113543.jpg

media.description:
The view through 4x floppy disk
Nothing
media.title: 20150920_161203.jpg

media.description:
The view through 4x floppy disk
Nothing
media.title: 20150920_161218.jpg

media.description: The sun through 2x floppy disk
media.title: 20150920_161352.jpg

media.description:
The sun through 2x floppy disk zoomed in.

Note it is not purple.
media.title: 20150920_161358.jpg

media.description: View through 1x floppy disk
media.title: 20150920_161442.jpg

media.description:
My shadow through 1x floppy disk

Note bright patches in plants, wheels, and fire hydrant in distance.
media.title: 20150920_161958.jpg

media.description:
The sun through 3 exposed film leaders

Pure IR
media.title: 20150920_161546.jpg

media.description:
Enhanced picture through 2 or 3 film leaders with maximum exposure.  
Hard to see, but IR signal present.
Try right click and view image in a dark room.
media.title: 20150920_161608.jpg

media.description:
Enhanced picture in direct sunlight through two film leaders.
The hot red portion is very bright visible light leaking through, but the blue hue of the sky is IR.
media.title: 20150920_161632.jpg

media.description:
Enhanced picture across street.  
Bright IR/visible signal on house, IR bright sky, dark vegetation.
media.title: 20150920_161705.jpg

media.description:
Enhanced IR picture of my shadow.
Bright red optical/IR back scatter from pavement, but bright IR response from some vegitation above.
media.title: 20150920_161715.jpg

comments.author: Jason Lambert
comments.comment: Could removing all but the blue channel in photoshop achieve the desired effect?

comments.author: Scott Williamson
comments.comment:
I think the photo is pretty cool as is ;-)
It'd make a good album cover.

Yes, I think filtering a narrow purple hue would isolate the IR.  I've used these film leaders with black and white IR cameras before and the results are dramatic, I think the lenses in my phone have coatings and/or the CCD has pigments designed to filter IR to improve the color quality of photos.
